caption.p: Overview of experimental and field studies with Schmallenberg virus in domestic ruminants contributing to our understanding of the efficacy of transplacental crossing, the capacity to induce congenital malformations, and the relationship between clinical and pathological malformations observed at birth in offspring and the moment of gestation at which the dam became infected

tr.td: Preliminary data; indications for efficient placental crossing but limited capacity to induce malformations
Schmallenberg virus: Final Report EU, 2014 c
Preliminary data; indications for efficient placental crossing but limited capacity to induce malformations
Schmallenberg virus: Final Report EU, 2014 c
Evidence of transplacental SBV infection only found in 13% of calves at birth; only 1 calf with malformations
SBV genome was detectable in at least one organ system of 18 out of 35 foetuses, but limited capacity to induce malformations
Preliminary data; indications of transplacental crossing in 64% of foetuses at 7 DPI; no malformations observed
Schmallenberg virus: Final Report EU, 2014 c
Evidence of transplacental SBV infection only found in 14% of lambs at birth; no congenital malformations observed
Evidence of transplacental SBV infection; no congenital malformations observed; Placenta of 5 ewes contained infectious SBV at birth
Preliminary data; several haemorrhagic and small foetuses observed after SBV infection
Schmallenberg virus: Final Report EU, 2014 c
13 cows with early foetal death after SBV infection

table-wrap-foot.p: Table adapted from De Regge et al. (2017) [ 226]. Exp Experiment, NS Not specified, C Cattle, S Sheep, G Goats, DPI Days post inoculation
aInoculum consisting of bovine serum collected 3 days post SBV infection, prepared and distributed by Friedrich Loeffler Institute

bSchmallenberg virus, March 2014, Technical and scientific studies, Final Report for the European Union Commission implementing Decision of 27 June 2012: available online at library.wur.nl/WebQuery/wurpubs/fulltext/310772
